awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Unlocking the fundamental mechanisms that underlie selectivity in oleochemical producing enzymes
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineering, mathematics, biochemistry, and biology are combined to develop strategies for converting renewable resources into higher-value chemicals and materials. Some of these products have never been produced biologically, so organisms need to be modified to make this possible. There is also a great need for computational tools that can predict beneficial modifications to cellular proteins, thereby guiding these efforts. This research project is developing novel proteins that are active in the sustainable production of fats and oils. If successful, this work has the potential to displace unsustainable and environmentally unfriendly processes that contribute to the deforestation of tropical regions. Research experiences for undergraduate students and outreach efforts directed at K-12 students and the public through the SCIENCountErs program are being provided and serve to enhance the development of a highly knowledgeable STEM workforce.  The efforts are enhancing our understanding of the techniques, capabilities, and limitations of protein design. 

In this collaborative research project, researchers are integrating computational and experimental methods to develop software that will be used to design novel enzymes involved in oleochemical metabolism. This protein-design infrastructure is integrating recent developments in molecular modeling and machine learning and developing design rules for tailoring chain length specificity for three oleochemical-synthesizing enzymes. These novel enzymes are being deployed in microbial biocatalysts and evaluated for their ability to produce oleochemicals from renewable resources. Upon conclusion, this work will generate a deeper understanding of selectivity in oleochemical metabolism, novel enzymes and microbial biocatalysts for producing specialty oleochemicals, and enzyme-design capabilities that could be widely applied in synthetic biology applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Using our suite of engineered Escherichia coli strains, we tested the mutagenesis predictions made by our computational collaborator. Using their in-house protein design software (IPRO), they designed new variants of thioesterases predicted to have altered specificity towards producing medium chain (8-12 carbon) fatty acids. A total of 27 designed enzymes produced significant levels of octanoic acid (8 carbon fatty acid) and three designed enzymes produced dodecanoic acid (12 carbon fatty acid) at the expense of the natively produced tetradecanoic acid (14 carbon fatty acid) as revealed by cell-based fatty acid production assays. In a separate study, we used a novel genetic selection to screen a random mutagenesis library of an 8-carbon specific thioesterase. Of the first 100 variants tested in the same cell-based assay, we identified a variant with a 15-fold increase in the maximum reaction rate. This enzyme was used to catalyze the key step in metabolic pathways for producing octanoic acid, 1-octanol, methyl-heptanone, and poly-hydroxyoctanoate. These pathways were introduced into engineered E. coli strains which were then shown to produce over 1 gram per liter of each product in cultures. We built a machine learning model of acyl-ACP reductases, an enzyme class used to make fatty alcohols, to guide the selection of chimaeric proteins with enhanced activity. Finally, we built a machine learning based classification algorithm that is trained on sequence features from over a 100 functionally characterized thioesterases. The trained algorithm can predict the specificity of any given plant acyl-ACP thioesterase just by using its amino-acid sequence as input. Our method can be both utilized to characterize thioesterases with experimentally unknown specificities and to discover novel enzyme sequences with desired specificities. At UW-Madison, our project supported training opportunities for three PhD students and three undergraduates. The project was disseminated to the public through eight peer-reviewed publications, three patent applications, and more than ten public presentations at universities and national meetings. In summary, through the use of custom-designed computer algorithms and corroborative experimental studies, we have discovered several key aspects that govern substrate selectivity of thioesterases that both deepen our knowledge and enable more successful engineering of these enzymes. Further, we have shown that these improved enzymes lead to improved biocatalysts capable of producing value-added chemicals from renewable resources. Continued development of these tools could lead to sustainable chemical production strategies that displace fossil fuel use and/or unsustainable agricultural practices. Our successful collaboration will also motivate further interactions between computational and experimental researchers in STEM projects.

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2021
Modified by: Brian F Pfleger
